Award.AwardTitle: Direct Numerical Simulation and Experimental Validation of Electrohydrodynamic Fuel Atomization

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1034506
Desjardins

One approach to enhance the fuel atomization process is to capitalize upon the benefits of electrohydrodynamic (EHD) phenomena. There are many possible benefits to EHD aided atomization for combustion, such as smaller droplets, wider spray cone, and the ability to control or "tune" the spray for improved performance. The objective of the proposed work is to employ recently advanced, state-of-the-art numerical schemes to conduct direct numerical simulation (DNS) of EHD atomization and validate simulation results with experimental data. High-fidelity numerical simulations will employ recently developed adaptive interface transport techniques, coupled to a robust and accurate Navier-Stokes/Ghost fluid solver. A novel numerical scheme for EHD will be developed that incorporates both bulk dynamics and surface effects in order to achieve realistic predictions of liquid break-up and atomization. The combination of these numerical tools will permit full DNS of electrostatic-aided liquid atomization for high electric Reynolds number.

Intellectual Merit: EHD flows and sprays have drawn increasing interest in recent years, yet key questions regarding the complex interactions among electrostatic charge, electric fields, and the dynamics of atomizing liquids remain unanswered. Combining recently advanced numerical simulation tools with validation experiments will permit exploration of EHD atomization with unprecedented detail. The outcomes of this research will be a fundamental understanding of the dynamics of EHD atomization, and a point of departure for robust modeling of EHD sprays using advanced numerical methods or reduced order models.

Broader Impacts: Fundamental atomization statistics extracted from this project will benefit a large community by providing a theoretical foundation for new EHD model developments. Automotive and aircraft engines rely extensively on fine atomization of liquid fuels for complete and efficient combustion, and will therefore benefit from this research. The simulated flow visualizations and experimental results will be incorporated as pedagogical tools to support the graduate courses that both PIs teach. The experimental validation will be adapted for a hands-on learning module to support the undergraduate curriculum and K-12 outreach activities at the University of Colorado at Boulder (UCB) Integrated Teaching and Learning (ITL) Program (itll.colorado.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent experiments have shown that electro-hydrodynamics (EHD) have the capability to greatly enhance liquid atomization, i.e., the process by which a coherent liquid jet breaks up into droplets. As a consequence, EHD atomization could provide a revolutionary means to improve and control fuel atomization for increased performance and economy in engines used in transportation devices. However, very little is known about EHD atomization, and first principles computational modeling of such a complex and physics-rich flow represents a major challenge. The main objective of this project was to develop the computational techniques required for the simulation of EHD atomization, and to use these techniques to elucidate the physics of EHD atomization.

During this project, several new computational methods were developed that greatly advance the state of the art in turbulent multiphysics liquid-gas flow simulations. In particular, a new family of Volume of Fluid schemes that provide exact conservation properties, provable second order accuracy, and the capability of transporting discontinuous variables, was developed, tested, and disseminated. Further, a rapid and accurate extrapolation scheme was introduced, with wide applicability in computational sciences. These techniques enabled for the first time the large-scale numerical simulation of EHD atomization. It was first confirmed that EHD has the capability to greatly enhance liquid breakup. It was further shown that Coulombic repulsion within the charged liquid jet is the main driver for atomization enhancement. Finally, it was established that during the timescale of liquid breakup, electric charge drift within the liquid jet is minimal, and that consequently a "frozen charge" EHD model is more appropriate than the classical "leaky dielectric" EHD model.

The computational model for multiphase EHD flows developed in this project can be used to improve the design, performance, and analysis of liquid fuel injection systems. The insights gained from this work can therefore be used to reduce the environmental impact of the many liquid-fueled combustion devices needed for modern life.

Several students, including PhD, Master of Science, and undergraduate, were involved in this research, and gained expertise in computational modeling, multiphase flow simulations, and manuscript preparation.
